Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2013 08:16AM - edited Jul 12, 2013 08:26AM by surfdreams I haven't had the greatest luck with ports. In '09, I had a wonderful port and never had an issue. Unfortunately, I had that one removed because I thought I was cured. Ha! My second port was put in 10/11. I had a lot of issues with it not working well, and they often had to use what I call the "roto rooter". It must clot at the end of the tube, and no matter how many pretzel acrobats I do, they can't get a return from it. The roto rooter flush usually works in clearing out whatever is blocking it. That port became infected and had to be removed 11/12 and a new port was placed. It worked well until a month or two ago. Now, they often can't get a blood return again - although the chemo goes in fine. (It's just like a man -  it takes, but doesn't give much in return ;-)    I hope this isn't deja vu as I'm running out of spots to put a port!  The technical term used in my medical report re: the roto rooter: 10 cc NS and 5 cc 100 U/ml Heparin. It stays in the line for 30 minutes, and then a bloodflow can usually be elicited. I get my chemo 2 Fridays on - one Friday off, so it's not going long periods without use. I hope it at least keeps receiving for a very long long long time!

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2012 09:04PM surfdreams wrote: there's an el (elevated) train that runs from the airport to the downtown area. Looking at the cta (transit authority) site, it looks like with one transfer, you could take the el all the way from the airport to the conference location. I live in downstate Illinois and visit Chicago once or twice a year. I drive there and then park my car and take public transportation as it's easier and cheap. Chicago has a great transit system. Very user friendly, and the ride from the airport to the downtown area is safe. You could call the CTA and ask them to mail you a map of their train/bus system. You'll receive one in about a week. You can also purchase a one day or 3 day CTA pass which allows you to use their buses and el trains unlimited for that period of time. Great way to get around in the city.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2014 08:14PM surfdreams wrote: Sorry you had such a rough go, Carolben! I usually had an easy time of this drug, so I was hoping you would have the same experience. They did have to back me off a few times over the course of treatment to my current regime of every 3 weeks due to low platelets and wbc, but I'm very fortunate that it's kept me stable. I also had zometa infusions at the same time as a bone strengthener, and I was having flu symptoms with the combo of all those together, so now my Zometa infusion is a week after the gem/carb, and it's worked well to separate them out.  Recently had a problem though, and am hoping someone here will have words of wisdom for me:   I'm pasting in a post that I wrote in another forum because I"m too lazy to re-write it:  My gemzar/carboplatin combo may soon be at an end. I've been getting these infusions since March 2013 - then suddenly, midstream through my carbo last Friday, I started having an allergic reaction - breathing got very tight. Hands and feet were burning. Face flushed - my BP and Pulse went way up, and oxygen went down to 88. I've seen the nurses in there rush around for a patient before, but this time, it was my turn. They quickly stopped the carbo and started fluids and benadryl. That got it back under control, but apparently, that often happens - suddenly you become allergic to the carboplatin. My onc. is going to try it again in 3 weeks with benadryl as a pre-med, but I'm already very nervous about it repeating. From what I've read on dr. google - once you have that reaction (which can quickly go into anaphylactic shock or respiratory arrest), you'll remain allergic to it. I've also read though, that a person can go through a desensitization regimen and then continue on the carboplatin. It involves getting it very slowly over a 24 hour period in a hospital, and then after that - you're desensitized and can have normal infusions again. I'll be talking to her about that prior to the next chemo. Has anyone else ever had this experience? I don't want to give up on it as it has kept me stable and has been an easy chemo for me thus far - plus, as a triple negative, I don't want to blow through my short list of chemos too quickly!

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2014 07:34PM surfdreams wrote: Wonderful news, Hindsfeet! It sounds like you're responding great to your chemo. Good to see you again, Glenna. I started out on the Carbo/Gemzar combo 3/13, with a regimen  of 3 weeks on, and one week off. Due to my platelets taking a hit, they backed it off to 2 and 2, then 1 and 2, now I'm at once every 3 weeks. I get a Neupogen shot twice the week prior to chemo to keep my platelets up. And yes - so far so good. It's been a kind chemo for me and I've stayed stable even with backing it off to every 3 weeks. I seemed to have an allergic reaction to it in July during infusion, and so now when i get it every 3 weeks, it's done over about 10 hours - a desensitizing procedure, which is allowing me to stay on it. To me, it's worth it, because it's been my favorite chemo (one of the oncology nurses thinks it's funny that I call it my favorite chemo - apparently, she's not been on the receiving end of the red devil chemo! So my point is.... I hadn't heard that they could back it off to every 4 weeks as your MO did for you - but it's good to hear that it can be done and still keep you stable. You needed that nice little chemo break! You've had a lot on your plate! Hope Mom's adjusting well. It sounds like a stressful but a good trip! Welcome back!

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2014 08:28PM surfdreams wrote: Dr. Google diagnosed my mets. I had symptoms of Horner's Syndrome (one eye appeared to be sunken in due to lung tumor pressing on a nerve). And I had continuous shoulder pain, and some shortness of breath. My general practice doctor wasn't concerned, but I was persistent and asked for chest X-ray. What could it hurt, I asked? So she agreed, and sent me to an eye doctor and for an MRI for the eye. Sure enough - I was right (thanks Dr. Google), and the X-rays showed multiple pulmonary nodules. She then sent me for a CT Scan and a lung biopsy to see what we were dealing with. If I hadn't been persistent in asking for the chest x-ray, I don't know how long I would have gone before diagnosis. Divine - On my CT Scan- it refers to multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules consistent with metastatic disease and gives measurements of the larger ones.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2012 08:15AM surfdreams wrote: Claudine - so sorry you had to join us. I was DX 13 months ago - TN with mets to lungs. I was originally DX in 2009 with stage 2. I have a daughter still at home, and a son who just graduated from college this year. A year ago, I didn't think I would even see that. I've had a kind chemo for the past year and (knocking on wood) it has kept me stable. I wouldn't say I feel better physically now then I did a year ago, but I don't feel worse. I've had some complications this year, but not due to the lung mets - problems with heart tachycardia and port infection. I've still been able to work, take vacations, and all the other fun and mundane things that go along with life. I've read on  these boards that some women don't have any complications in their life at all with the lung mets. I do get winded easily, but otherwise, they and the chemo don't slow me down much. It will get easier after some time to deal with the idea of Stage IV. When first diagnosed, my MO told me I would have time to get my affairs in order. I'd say I've beaten that prognosis, as I've had plenty of time, but my trips on De-Nial have kept me from doing as much as I needed to. I don't feel like I need to do it today, either. It sucks that you've got mets. It sucks more that you're young and your daughter is young. I don't have anything to say that will make that all better. It sucks. This board and the lovely lovely women here have been a  huge support and comfort for me. Everyone's journey is different, but there are so many here who are walking similar paths with me and that makes for a much more bearable journey. I come here often. Sometimes I post, but most of the time, I read what others are sharing, and it helps me. You might also speak to your doctor about medication that will help you cope on a day to day basis or on an "as needed" basis, because there are sure difficult days. I have medication to take the edge off of some days, but don't use it often. Those days seem to come in spurts for me. I'm so glad I have something to take when I need it. And everything that Michelle said above - I agree 100%. It does get easier after awhile, but the limbo time is wicked. Hang in there. Hugs to you!{{{}}}

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2012 04:08AM - edited Jul 6, 2012 04:11AM by surfdreams I've had two ports. Both times, felt like I'd been punched hard in the chest for a couple of days after they were implanted - nothing that tylenol didn't help with though. First port worked great 100% of the time, but I chose to take it out when my chemo rounds were finished because I thought I was done with cancer. Fooled me. 2nd port doesn't work as well - so far, they can always get the chemo to go in, but can't get blood return to come out - so still often have to get labs via my veins. Still, I'm so thankful to have my port as my veins roll and are difficult to get. I couldn't imagine having to go through all the sticking they would have to do everytime to do chemo (weekly). I didn't like the placement of the first port - it was up by my collar bone and the tubing ran up my neck in my jugular vein. I could feel it in my neck and it was uncomfortable. The 2nd port is put lower on my chest and I like it there much better as it's much more comfortable. Even though it's not good for blood returns, I'm very thankful to have the port for the chemo. I lather it up with prescription Lidocaine cream about an hour prior to chemo. Cover it with a little piece of "glad press and seal" plastic wrap and tape the edges to keep it on there till they're ready to access it. I have forgotten to put it on a few times, and it's no big deal to access without numbing. Just feels like anther needle stick. The needle they use looks like it should hurt more than that, but I think that, because the port is so close to the surface of the skin, it doesn't hurt bad at all. Good luck Lynn!

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2015 08:20AM - edited Apr 23, 2015 08:21AM by surfdreams Betsy - I'm going to steal a few of these women's words as they are very wise. Please don't give up on the wedding. (Most) Doctors are wonderful, but they don't know everything, and none have a crystal ball. Please know that many women (me included) live well beyond that initial estimate that they're given. Don't live like your Dr.s estimate is accurate. With that estimate however, you would be eligible for hospice, and that may not be forever either. If you rally, you may graduate from that program as well. But in the meantime, they're the experts to help get your pain under control, and to provide you, your husband and family with a lot of help and support. Don't feel like you need to wrap your head around this crappy diagnosis right now. Why should you? You were just handed a vile piece of information. I don't think we're wired to say "Okay. I understand and I accept". That's not the way the human spirit works in my opinion. You're in my thoughts, and please know we're all here rooting for you. Please keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 09:19AM surfdreams wrote: I think it was CoolBreeze who posted on here once in answer to a similar question: When you find out you're stage IV, the first two rules are: 1. Do not google life expectancies. 2. Do not google life expectancies. I'm not sure I'm quoting her exactly, but it was along those lines - rule 1 & 2 being the same, and that has stuck with me. I agree with that wholeheartedly. Those statistics online don't take into account the individuals who died of something non-cancer related. And if that's the average, it means that there's lots over that mark as well as under. Also remember that those statistics might be 10 or 20 years old - done prior to all the new medications that have come out since that study began. Lots of variables.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 10:49PM - edited Apr 3, 2014 10:50PM by surfdreams OK Fitztwins - I have a need to revive your thread after the evening I just had. I've just finished my 46th hour on the phone with insurance hassles since November. Much of the time it is spent on hold with Blue Cross Blue Shield, but tonight, it was my other favorite - the Federal Marketplace.    2 hours tonight. When I signed up with it in December, it wouldn't allow me to add my daughter, saying she might be eligible for our state's kidcare program. I just received notice 2 weeks ago that we made $1300 too much for her to be eligible, so I decided to add her to my policy via the Martketplace website. Adding my daughter to my policy created a whole new level of GYAAAAAAAA!!!!!!!! It cancelled my old policy and maybe/maybe not started a new policy over from scratch (although I've already met my yearly deductible).  Truth is stranger than fiction. I told the Fed supervisor that I needed to know if I still have insurance, as I have chemo in 12 hours. She said "what will happen if you don't get chemo in 12 hours?"  I said "the cancer will progress". She said "would you die in the next 24 to 48 hours if you don't get it?" I said no. She said "then it's not considered an emergency." I might just die from a stroke from dealing with these &**$%#%$! If you see a huge smoke cloud coming from the midwest - it's not a fire - it's coming from my head!

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 08:55AM surfdreams wrote: Agree with the DivineMrsM - I haven't had any problems reading the techs prior to both my diagnoses. In my initial mammogram, even my untrained eye knew there was a problem, as I could see the screen from where I stood at the crusher machine. One breast image looked black - the other breast had a big white spidery blob in it. The tech excused herself for quite awhile before coming back to take more views of the one breast. In my first ct scan to dx the mets last October, the tech was very nice and very chatty. After the scan, she walked out with me and seemed down, and as our ways parted, she said "You'll be in my thoughts". Doesn't take a clairvoyant to read either one of those clues though. A friend's husband was recently dx with bladder cancer. He went to the same ct tech prior to being diagnosed. I told her my experience (we jokingly refer to this tech as "poker face"). I wished I hadn't told her my experience when he called her after his scan and said that she told him "I'll be thinking of you". Sure enough - it was cancer.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2015 12:00AM surfdreams wrote: jen1 - you can be worried, but the one thing you shouldn't be is a compliant patient. One of the many lessons I've learned since my stage IV dx, is that you have to be proactive in your care. Before being diagnosed, I had enough concerns to address them with my primary care physician, who didn't take my concerns seriously. She wasn't going to order the chest x-ray i requested. I stuck with the request, repeatedly asking , what could it hurt? She eventually caved and ordered it, and guess what? It was lung mets. (the clue factor for me was shoulder pain and horner's syndrome). There have been numerous other times that if I hadn't spoken up, things would have been missed or not done. Don't sit back and wait for a dr. to take you seriously if you have concerns. Stick with it and be the squeaky wheel. I'm not obnoxious, or rude, or disrespectful, but I am persistent. We have to be. They have lots of patients to take care of. Don't allow yourself to be one who falls through the cracks because you don't speak up. Best wishes and keeping my fingers crossed for you.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2014 05:02AM surfdreams wrote: Well, I put my foot in my mouth at chemo today, but it was still funny - in a black humor kind of way. I went today for just a quick Zometa infusion - takes about 1/2 hour. They directed me to sit in one of the chairs in a certain row.  I had always thought the people sitting in that row were more sickly than the others in the infusion room as it was close to the nurse's desk. But as I walked down the row of chairs, I noticed that everyone in that row had just one or two small IV bags.  I said aloud to the gentleman across from me, "Oh, this must be where they put the people who won't be here very long". He started laughing, and I quickly tried to correct myself, and said "I mean, this must be the area for the short timers". He started laughing more, and he said "It's not getting any better". I agreed with him and told him I just need to shut my mouth. I think only he and one other woman heard me and they were both laughing, so I hope I didn't offend, but to me, it was funny.  Someone posted on the favorite quotes thread one by Jimmy Buffet. I think it was "if we don't laugh, we'll go crazy". True that!  And to the previous posters - I'm an Illinois girl too, and yes- the snow and the cold was horrendous. I would love to live somewhere with no snow! On the bright side: it's all melting now!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2013 08:47AM - edited Aug 23, 2013 08:48AM by surfdreams Don't kick yourself over past decisions. You're not the same person now that you were then, and yes - I agree completely that you have to put it into context of what you were dealing with at the time. I mean no offense to the very young ladies on the forums, because I can only speak for myself when I say all of my major life decisions were made when I was in my late teens and early twenties, and I was making lousy decisions at that age. I  was fortunate enough  to go to college, though I didn't take it as seriously as I should and I wish I could have a "do-over" there. And I chose a very fulfilling path, but one that does not pay well at all. At the time I said that I didn't care if I made money or not - just so I'm happy. I've since decided that I could have also been happy in a career making much more money. My college age son said the same lame statement to me a few years ago and I screamed. He thought that was pretty funny, but he did tweak his expectations a bit and is making OK money doing what makes him happy. In those tender years, I chose my life career path, chose my husband, chose to have children, chose to buy my house, put down roots in a small community,  etc. The years haven't been easy for many reasons, including the fact that I didn't have the experiences of life I have now, but I choose to have no regrets. If I could go back and do things over, who's to say that I would make the best choices even now?

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2015 10:10AM surfdreams wrote: kaayborg - I seem to be on the 2 year plan. Every two years, something changes with my cancer. I was stage 2 in 2009, but went to stage 4 in 2011. Started Abraxane at that time, and it kept me stable till 2013, when I started the Gemzar/Carbo for bone mets. 2 years later - this year in May, had brain mets which required whole brain radiation and gamma knife. Chemo isn't very effective for brain mets due to the blood brain barrier, so surgery or rads are the options. now that my brain treatment is done, my oncologist would like to err on the side of caution and talk me into restarting the Gemxar/Carbo, but as long as nothing is lighting up on my PET scan, I am ready to let it ride till something lights up again. I feel great (knocking on wood here), and will restart chemo when things start going south again, but so far, I'm enjoying this big chemo holiday. I'm hoping to get at least 2 years out of it! The desensitization protocol involves infusion over a long period of time. My day with that consisted of being the first patient of the day, and the last to leave. I would first get IV steroids and ant-nausea meds and IV benadryl. Then the Gemzar was administered as normal. Then the Carboplatin was started as a very slow drip. Through the course of the day, it would slowly be sped up, but still administered slower than usual. The total day's infusion would take about 9 hours.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2015 05:34PM surfdreams wrote: Good luck to all you Gemzar - Carboplatin girls. I started this regimen in 2013 and had great success with it. I originally was on one week on and one week off, but also had to back off several times, to my final regimen of once every 3 weeks. This allowed my platelets to recover (with the help of Neupogen shots about 4 days and 1 day prior to each chemo. I had an allergic reaction to Carboplatin after a year - during infusion, but I didn't want to stop the chemo as it had been easy for me to tolerate and we triple negative girls have a limited number of chemos available to us. I googled this problem and saw that other doctors were using a de-sensitizing procedure to be able to continue using Carboplatin after an allergic reaction. I showed the literature to my Oncologist, and she worked with their Pharmacist to come up with a de-sensitization protocol, and I continued on that for another year. My last chemo was in May. Later in May, I had some very concerning symptoms, and MRI revealed mets to the brain. My chemo was stopped at that time to deal with the brain mets. I had Whole Brain Radiation, and then in August, had Gamma Knife performed on the brain mets. About a week after that, I had my first PET Scan. The benefits of a Pet Scan are that any active cancer lights up like a Christmas Tree. My miraculous news is that nothing lit up in my lungs. A couple of bone mets still lit up, so I had radiation on those. I just had another PET scan earlier this week, and no active cancer is lighting in my lungs still, and the mets they radiated in my bones are showing up as scar tissue now. One of the 2 brain mets is completely gone, and the other one is continuing to shrink away. I am feeling very blessed these days. God is good. I think that they have come a long way with cancer medications and that there is hope.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2013 05:59PM surfdreams wrote: I have neuropathy this time around as well, but it is the tingly feeling - not painful yet - just lets me know that it's there. The first time around with chemo, the neuropathy was painful, and my Oncologist put me on 300 mg. Neurontin at night. It is a seizure med, but also helps with the Neuropathy. The other nice side effect of this dosage was that I slept like a log and woke up feeling so rested. I don't think I even rolled over at night. I know of other people that had it prescribed for this as 100 mg. a couple of times throughout the day, so they didn't get that big benefit of sleeping hard at night. If your insurance doesn't cover it, it is a medication that has been around for a long time, so it's cheap. Something to think about if the supplements don't work.

Lots of good information here, and lots of people who are on similar journeys as you. Please don't freak or panic. It sounds like your Oncologist is making wise decisions to get a handle on your treatment. Things will settle down once you have a treatment plan in place. In the meantime, please take time to breathe and to process your news. Please keep us posted on what you find out at the research center. Triple Negative is aggressive, but on the bright side (if there is a bright side), it often responds better to treatment than the positives. Hang in there, and come back here often. ;-)
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2014 09:43AM - edited Jan 4, 2014 09:48AM by surfdreams Spirit Blessings - I had a good run with Abraxane for 15 months. If you search these boards for Abraxane, you'll find lots of women who have had good success with this chemo and, although it's not side effect free, it is usually a very do-able chemo. I went 3 weeks on and 1 week off. I lost my hair (but some just get thinning hair so I wouldn't shave it until you see what it will do to you). Another common side effect is nails lifting and turning black - some women have them fall off. My NP suggested that I put vinegar in my dish water to kill fungus that can grow under the lifting nails. They're painful and look gross - the best advice I got from these boards was to keep them polished and cut short so they wouldn't catch on things to pull them back. A good hardening polish seems to save the nails. The other nice part of this is that you don't have to look at them being so icky. I used Sally Hanson Hard as Nails and never lost a nail and they returned to normal over time. Neuropathy is common, but mine isn't debilitating by any means. I had shortness of breath, but I still do, so I'm thinking it's the lung mets causing that. My feet swell with every chemo I have ever had. They would give me an anti-nauseau pre-med with the chemo. I would also take Immodium after chemo as I often had diarea for a few hours afterwards. All of these symptoms improved after the first 6 months. My nails re-attached and hair even started re-growing - though very very slowly! Drink lots and lots of water. Carry eye lubricating drops with you for when eyes get stingy and watery. That's the bad and the ugly of my experience. As for the good - I was able to continue working and living life pretty normally. I never got sick with it. I would get tired. But otherwise, I felt good. I have a chemo that's good to me now too overall, but I miss Abraxane being in my arsenal. It's one I would definitely be fine with doing again! I hope it treats you well.  Mamasboy - have you invited your mother to read and post on this site? We would love to meet her. There are  some sites here that deal with recipes and nutrition that might be very helpful for her as well. And I wouldn't call us brave. We're doing what we have to do, just like most others would do when they find themselves in our shoes. There are lots of chemos out there to try, and I'm hoping her radiation shrinks that tumor down to a size where they can get rid of it. You can always get other opinions as well if you're unsure of her current treatment. Best wishes, and tell her to jump on here as she sounds like a great lady!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 08:03PM surfdreams wrote: MaryH - so glad your scans were good, and you've got a new arrow to draw from you quiver. I"m keeping my fingers crossed that it treats you right.  I've got a date with the couch tonight. I had a bladder biopsy today. My CT scan 2 weeks ago showed my bladder was odd shaped and an area of "concern" in my bladder. Followed up quickly with a cystoscope that revealed an area - the likes of which - my Urologist said he didn't know what it was - he had never seen anything like it before. With that crazy bedside manner quote, he sent me on my way with 10 days of penicillin and then back today for the biopsy. My concern was that on the CT scan, it showed the area lighting up in my bladder and including the fat outside the bladder, so I'm thinking a tumor that extended through the bladder which is never good - according to dr. google - often results in losing the bladder. I went into the bladder biopsy with platelets of only 75 (he was hoping for at least 100), but said he would cauterize it good. I'm still here, so obviously, that part went ok. He said the area looked better and smaller than it did when he saw me 10 days ago. So that's a good sign, since tumors don't respond to Penicillin x 10 days. Makes it more likely that it was an irritation from a bad bladder infection. I'm breathing a little sigh of relief to at least have it behind me. I'll breathe a bigger (huge in fact) in 10 days when the biopsy results are back showing that there isn't a new tumor and I can keep my bladder. After all these years, my bladder and I have become pretty attached. Thank goodness for anesthesia and Ativan! I hope everyone's holding their own these days!

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2014 11:05PM surfdreams wrote: Great news, Lostinmo!!! Sorry to hear your not so great news, Brenda! Here's hoping that Abraxane will be your magic bullet!  My gemzar/carboplatin combo may soon be at an end as well. I've been getting these infusions since March 2013 - then suddenly, midstream through my carbo last Friday, I started having an allergic reaction - breathing got very tight. Hands and feet were burning. Face flushed - my BP and Pulse went way up, and oxygen went down to 88. I've seen the nurses in there rush around for a patient before, but this time, it was my turn. They quickly stopped the carbo and started fluids and benadryl. That got it back under control, but apparently, that often happens - suddenly you become allergic to the carboplatin. My onc. is going to try it again in 3 weeks with benadryl as a pre-med, but I'm already very nervous about it repeating. From what I've read on dr. google - once you have that reaction (which can quickly go into anaphylactic shock or respiratory arrest), you'll remain allergic to it. I've also read though,  that a person can go through a desensitization regimen and then continue on the carboplatin. It involves getting it very slowly over a 24 hour period in a hospital, and then after that - you're desensitized and can have normal infusions again. I'll be talking to her about that prior to the next chemo.  Has anyone else ever had this experience? I don't want to give up on it as it has kept me stable and has been an easy chemo for me thus far - plus, I don't want to blow through a short list of chemos too quickly!

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2012 03:18PM surfdreams wrote: i've not heard of needing the nail polish to be dark. I've been on the Abraxane infusions for a year now and thought I would lose all my nails. I kept them polished with a light frosty polish - sally Hanson's Hard as Nails polish when they started lifting and looking gross. Now, still on Abraxane, they've all re-attached, except for one thumbnail, and no longer hurt. The thumbnail is the last hold out, but even it's getting better and I won't lose it at this point. keep them trimmed super short so they don't catch on anything because, Boy, does THAT hurt when there's so little of them attached anway. Something my MO's nurse practitioner shared with me was also to put vinegar in the water when I was washing dishes as the acid in the vinegar will kill any fungus that might want to grow under the nails when they're loose. Sometimes,  I just soaked my nails in some warm vinegar water while I was watching TV. Something worked. They're doing much better. I also lost my hair on Abraxane, and it has grown back, though still too thin to go topless - and when did it turn gray??? I had the bone pain that I was sure was bone mets, but so far, bone scans ruled that out, and the pain is improved. Abraxane has it's downsides, but it's also sure got it's perks - like keeping the cancer stable so far.....I'll take it. Best of luck with your treatments!
